prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in G244.8+54.9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will map [CII] line emission in Band 8 at 0.3" resolution for a source size of 2".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use the SPIRE 500-mu measurement to estimate the continuum flux density, and our measured FIR luminosity and the observed L(CO)/L(FIR)=1.5d-3 from Stacey et al, (2010) to estimate our line flux requirements. The FWHM is estimated from our CO line profiles. The source size of 2" is estimated from NIR imaging, and agrees with upper limits on the CO size just obtained from 2" IRAM interferometry. For G244.8 we expect a ([CII]) flux of 747.7 Jy km/s, and a peak flux density of 1.2 Jy km/s for a 630 km/s wide line. Using the ETC we find we can reach 8 mJy rms in a 75 km/s channel in 23. min on-source, and 1.1 hrs of total integration time. This will give SNR=150 for the total source and be sufficient to map the source with a 0.3" beam. This corresponds to weather conditions in the 1st octile.
We place additional sub-bands on the continuum to enable good mapping of the star-formation and dust properties (spectral index, temperatures).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in G045.1+61.1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will map [CII] in Band 8 in this source at 0.3" resolution, which has a size of 3" seen with Spitzer.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use the SPIRE 500 mu measurement as estimate of the continuum flux density and our measured FIR luminosity and the observed L(CO)/L(FIR)=1.5d-3 from Stacey et al, (2010) to estimate our line flux requirements. The FWHM is estimated from our CO line profiles. The source size of 1"x3" is estimated from Spitzer/IRAC imaging, which suggests we are seeing an elongated arc, that might well be unresolved perpendicular to the lensing axis. In G080.3 where we already have both Spitzer and (sub-)mm interferometry at subarc resolution (see scientific justification) the SPITZER contours match those of the dust and CO. 045.3 we expect a ([CII]) flux of 269.5 Jy km/s, and a peak flux density of 0.8 Jy km/s for a 270 km/s wide line. Using the ETC we find we can reach 8 mJy rms in a 75 km/s channel in 4 min on-source, and 32' of total integration time at an observed frequency of 434 GHz. This will give SNR=100 for the total source and be sufficient to map the source with a 0.3" beam. This corresponds to weather conditions in the 1st octile. We place additional subbands on CO(16-15) and two continuum tunings.

We use the SPIRE 500 mu measurement as estimate of the continuum flux density and our measured FIR luminosity and the observed L(CO)/L(FIR)=1.5d-3 from Stacey et al, (2010) to estimate our line flux requirements. The FWHM is estimated from our CO line profiles. From our experience with other Dusty Gems and comparable sources in the literature (e.g. Cosmic Eyelash, Swinbank et al. 2011), we expect to find one or several arc of 1-3" length, probably unresolved in the direction perpendicular to the lensing axis. We expect a ([CII]) flux of 300 Jy km/s, and a peak flux density of 1.2 Jy km/s for a 270 km/s wide line. Using the ETC we find we can reach 8 mJy rms in a 75 km/s channel in 2 min on-source, and 31' min of total integration time at an observed frequency of 490 GHz. This will give SNR=140 for the total source and be sufficient to map the source with a 0.3" beam. This corresponds to weather conditions in the 1st octile.to enable good mapping of the star-formation and dust properties (spectral index, temperatures).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: OH in G244.8+54.9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Goal is to map OH in this galaxy, which has a an extraordinary continuum brightness, reaching a peak brightness at 1 Jy. OH seen in absorption would be an excellent probe of molecular outflows at high-z, which is prohibitively difficult to obtain for almost all other high-z galaxies. This is a unique experiment enabled by this outstanding source.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimate the continuum flux density at 627 GHz by extrapolating along our SPIRE 250, 350, 500 mu, JCMT/Scuba2 850 mu, and IRAM/GISMO 2mm SED.
We list the continuum flux for this Science Goal instead of the Line flux, since this determines the SNR of absorption-line detections. From Sturm et al. (2011) and Fischer et al. (2010) we expect a depth of about 20-30%, potentially more given the high molecular gas fractions of high-z starbursts.
The ETC suggests that at 627 GHz, where the sky transparency is at >80% of the maximum of Band 9 (as suggested by the spectral setup tool), we can reach rms=5 mJy in 20' of on-source observing, or 1.14 hrs total. This is for 1st octile weather and a channel width of 75 km/s. For a continuum flux of 510 mJy, this correspond to SNR=100. This will be sufficient to probe a line with a depth of 10% of the continuum flux at SNR=10, nearby galaxies suggest depths of about 30%, which would be easier to probe. We will observe the source at 1" resolution and obtain this estimate for the integrated source, with the goal of probing the line out to the wings, where the absorption will be fainter. The wings are particularly interesting to constrain the terminal velocity of the wind. However, but having some spatial resolution in our observations, we hope to also locate the origin of the putative wind from the deepest parts of the absorption line. We place 4 subbands at adjacent frequencies to maximize our spectral coverage and enable an good continuum estimate.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The brightest, most strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies on the FIR/sub-mm sky provide unprecedented insight into the fine spatial details of the most vigorously star-forming galaxies in the early Universe. The Planck all-sky survey, complete down to 600 mJy (~5x10^13 L_s at z=2.5) and in combination with Herschel/SPIRE photometry, has enabled us to identify the brightest gravitationally lensed high-redshift galaxies on the sky, at spectroscopic redshifts z=2.2-3.6. As part of our comprehensive multi-wavelength follow-up of these extraordinary sources, we wish to use the ALMA 12-m-array to map the [CII] in the 3 sources observable from Chajnator, and to search for OH119, an excellent absorption-line probe of molecular outflows in G244.8, potentially the single brightest high-z lensed galaxy on the FIR sky. [CII] will provide us with the total UV heating budget and provide a base for a plethora of line diagnostics, including gas densities and radiation fields, when combined with various mm lines. Velocity gradients and line profiles will constrain gas turbulence and rotation, and may indicate a merger or winds.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
